node.text: Shooting the sun through the smoke. There’s a giant prominence on the sun that looks wild, I’m recording a timelapse of it

node.text: I’m often asked what the sun looks like through my solar telescope- this is as close as I can get to sharing that. Please don’t do this with a regular telescope, you will go blind!

node.text:
Curious about the science behind my shots and how they are captured? This is the complete livestream with astrophysicist and generally awesome person @astropartigirl ...make sure you check her page out, she’s doing an incredible collaboration with @cathrinmachin to produce images of the invisible forces at work in our universe!! You see the sneak peek at two of them but there is another one coming that sounds mind blowing. 

Send your questions about dark matter (and everything else) here ⬇️⬇️⬇️

node.title: Photos vs Art and the science behind them- with an astrophysicist!

node.text:
You asked for it, so of course I delivered. Two hours and 171,460 images of our star in 5 seconds, played forward and backwards. After 30 seconds it goes to 4x speed so you can see how much our star turns in that time! 

These are sunspots, and showing how the plasma dances around them in what’s known as an “active region”. Sometimes these create flares, powerful bursts of energy!

node.text:
Make sure to go outside tonight! Tonight you will see a very slim crescent moon next to a brilliant “star”. That star is actually Venus! Best seeing is right after sunset, look West. 

This is the first moon shot captured from new home in Arizona. It was created by using a powerful telescope at high magnification, and taking many pictures to create a mosaic of the entire moon. I captured Venus separately and incorporated it into the shot, as it was captured last night before they were so close. The Arizona sunsets make for some lovely colors. Swipe to see a high magnification shot of Venus, with even some subtle cloud detail visible!

node.text:
Saturn and Jupiter, my clearest photo of each so far.  Shown here in their respective sizes in the sky. Saturn is only slightly smaller than Jupiter without those rings, but over twice as far away! You can also see the moon Io in frame. These are also the first images captured from my new backyard in Arizona, showing me how much better the skies are now that I’m out of the Sacramento Valley. 

As I get settled I’ll go live during these captures to show off my setup and answer questions. Would that be something you would want to see?

node.text:
I’ve been seeing this 230 megapixel image shared everywhere lately saying it’s “the clearest picture of the sun, ever!” In true clickbait fashion. While I’m flattered, I’m pretty sure that’s not true. This image was captured 6 months ago from my (former) backyard, and at the time, it was definitely MY clearest photo of the sun ever. 

Since the image was making its rounds again, I decided to clean it up a little and relaunch it as an open-edition print, available for the first time on metal, and in larger sizes than previously offered. Check out the link in my bio if you want one. The full 230 megapixel image is available to patrons, that’s linked in my highlights.

On a side note, I’m starting to get settled in my new home in Arizona, so will hopefully begin shooting fresh content for you. My skies here are darker and clearer, so will be excellent for getting better images.

node.text:
Jupiter spins really, really fast. A full day on Jupiter is around 10 hours, so if you were standing on the equator you would be moving at 22,000mph. 

This is 4 hours of Jupiter’s rotation sped up. Even though Jupiter spins so fast, it is so large that the rotation still appears slow. Still though, during an observing session you can clearly see the planet subtly turning, as features drift in and out of view along the limb. The moons will move at a similar speed, and you can watch them cruise along easily. 

I’m smack dab in the middle of moving my entire life to Arizona, so this is actually a video from last year I reprocessed for you (did a better job color balancing, plus had some fun with the speed). After I get settled in my new place I’ll start sharing capturing new images again!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andrew McCarthy on August 21, 2021 tagging @optcorp. May be an image of sky and nature.

node.text:
Our moon, caught in the crepuscular rays of the setting sun. 

This composite image was created by capturing images both during the day and at night, to give you a unique view of our sky and possibly my favorite lunar portrait I’ve done. 

Early phases of the new moon are exciting to see on the horizon after sunset. I used to joke we were looking at God’s thumbnail, but what we’re seeing is so much more powerful than that. Our view of these phases helps us grasp our position in the cosmos, and a deeper understanding of the moon gives us a deeper understanding of ourselves. 

To pick up “Floating Through Sunshine” in print, check out my store, linked in my bio. Or just go to cosmicbackground.io.

node.text:
Saturn seems to get more love, but I find Jupiter to be more interesting to observe. In two days, the gas giant will be at its largest and brightest for the year. 

Jupiter is a fun target for amateurs to observe because even through low powered binoculars you can clearly see the 4 “Galilean” moons orbiting the planet. With higher magnification, the complex storms in the planet’s atmosphere become visible, with the Great Red Spot a prominent point of interest. While observing, you can watch the planet rotate. It has a 10-hour day, so thinks will swing out of view quickly. The moons move quickly too, transiting across the face or becoming occulted by the planet, sometimes casting a very visible shadow on the surface. 

If you want to try and find Jupiter in the sky, just look to the southwest just after sunset, it will look like a bright star rising. (Southern Hemisphere folks, you’ll be looking northwest).

This image is one I captured during Saturn’s opposition a week ago. Sadly most of my gear is boxed up for my move so it is unlikely I’ll be able to capture the planet on the day of opposition, but I will try.

node.text:
This is the second image that got me shortlisted for the astrophotographer of the year award, and remains my favorite transit picture I’ve captured so far. 

The time the station spent right on the terminator of the moon was about 1/100th of a second, so getting the timing and framing of everything just right was a huge challenge. 

This is also the second in a series of limited edition images I have available in print in limited quantities. They’re digitally signed and numbered, and available on paper or metal. This is the first time since May I’ve had my work available in print, so make sure you check out the link in my bio if you’re interested.

node.text:
This image got me shortlisted as astrophotographer of the year, and remains one of my favorite images of the sun ever. 

I’m sharing it now not just to brag about being shortlisted (there’s another image that got me on that list, I’ll post it in a couple days) but also because I just relaunched my website and now have my images available in METAL for the first time ever! This image was remastered as part of a new limited edition series that I’ll have available until they sell out. You’ll see many others on the site, and I’ll be adding more in the coming days. 

A huge thank you to everyone that supported my initial release in May. I had a series of technical issues that made it take much longer to send out orders than I’d like, which is why I had it deactivated for a while while I worked on them. Your support means the world to me, as without it I’d be back in a 9-5 and it’s unlikely I would be able to devote my time to capturing images of our sky. 

To check out the site or pick up a print, go to cosmicbackground.io or visit the link in my bio. I should have the shop’s integration with Instagram working soon as well.

node.text:
Another gem in the heart of the Milky Way, the lagoon nebula is actually visible with your naked eyes. 

A view through binoculars shows you a diffuse cloud tucked within the dark dust lanes of the galactic core. Through a decent telescope, that cloud begins to show structure, swaths of light and shadow sculpted by the birth of stars within its belly. 

With a camera, vivid details and colors emerge. If you captured it with a standard DSLR, the nebula looks pink with a bluish core. With an astronomy-specific camera, the near-infrared colors of hydrogen alpha invisible to the dslr dominate the view, creating a more uniform deep red image. By capturing it using various filters matching the emissions of gasses within the nebula and assigning them to specific color channels, incredible colors spring to life, where science meets art.
